entry.title: I Need More Hours in a Day!
entry.summary:
RubyCLR will only compile on Ruby 1.8.2. There, I said it. The pre-built runtime.dll will run on 1.8.4, but you will not be able to build. There are a whole pile of issues around getting it to build on 1.8.4 (and I believe on 1.8.5 as well).

I took a quick look last night during a break from my current battles in refactoring the existing RubyCLR codebase. In short, it’s not pretty. It also won’t be resolved until I finish refactoring the current codebase and writing some long-overdue documentation.

I would love to make it a higher-priority item, but unless someone can donate some time to figuring out what’s blocking compilation (and execution – there’s a nasty seg fault that happens when running nmake) this will have to go on the back-burner.

Now where did I put that human cloning book?

entry.title: Comment on I Need More Hours in a Day! by John Lam
entry.content: I use 1.8.2-15 Stable Release of the 1-click installer. You'll need to download the source code separately from http://raa.ruby-lang.org/project/ruby/1.8.2. Unzip / untar the source code into the same directory that you installed the 1-click installer (c:\ruby on my computer).

entry.title: Comment on I Need More Hours in a Day! by Kurtiss Hare
entry.content:
After a bit of messing around, I was able to build RubyCLR drop 4, using Visual C++ 2005 Express, the latest Microsoft Platform SDK for Windows Server 2003 SP1, and Ruby 1.8.5. If I remember correctly, the main hurdles I had to overcome were adding the proper environment vars to the Visual Studio 2005 command prompt:

INCLUDE=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Platform SDK\Include;%INCLUDE LIB=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Platform SDK\Lib;%LIB%

It's different per-architecture, but the x86 file is at VSDIR\Common 7\Tools\vsvars32.bat.

I added the Platform SDK Include directory to the project includes (alongside Ruby185 and Ruby185\win32). I built against msvcrt-ruby18.lib, ws2_32.lib, and ole32.lib, which live in the Platform SDK Lib directory, or ruby\lib.

Where are folks getting stuck?
